instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_F</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground because of a water spill that got under ub000. ppdcin stays at 5v. could this be the issue? i've replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips on that side

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_T_F</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
So you have a short there too.
In fact there are many other components connected.
If your short remains on pin 1 of LB190, then yes, UB000 is shorted.
Does the board start without LB190.
Check if PPDCIN pulses up every 5s at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: i've removed ub000 and the short is gone

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message:
"If your short remains on pin 1 of LB190..."
Next time check that.
Or you risk to remove a BGA chip and have same problem after.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: i checked LB190 and everything else before the bga chip was pulled. just wondering if that bga chip is necessary for those <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips to work

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: can this board work without ub000?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message:
Did you try it?
Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at least, without UB000?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: no i can't get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> because the ppcdin is only 5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message:
That is not a reason.
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> can generate 13V with 5V on input; didn't think you why are 2 MOSFET pairs on the new boards?
Just need SMC communicates with the external device which only generates 5V as normal.
If SMC cannot talk with the charger, it will also block <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
If UB000 is involved in the communication, no way to start the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message: so i need to put ub000 back to use this board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short under ub000
threads.message:
I cannot confirm that 100%.
But I think it needs to be soldered.
Maybe UB300/400 triy to establish a communication with it.

I don't think someone will remove it from an working board, just for test...
